src:
Ramón Villares: “Non podemos pensar a Galicia moderna sen aqueloutra Galicia americana”
05 Nov 2019, 05:38 by JOAQUIM VENTURA   


Portada do libro

En toda construción dunha identidade (xa que logo, con vocación nacional), hai diversas fases: delimitar o obxecto, atribuírlle a condición de suxeito e conseguir que os –cabería dicir- pacientes, os connacionais que o conforman, collan conciencia de tal singularidade. Claro está que pode suceder que os alleos lla concedan a ese obxecto-suxeito histórico sen que os naturais rematen de tomar conciencia.
Tal vez por iso, exercicios como o que ven facer Ramón Villares con Galicia. Una nación entre dos mundos (Pasado & Presente) queira explicar aos lectores non galegos a realidade histórica desta terra pero asemade o faga cun (involuntario?) exercicio de reflexión cuxos destinatarios serían os propios galegos.
De maneira simultánea pero cunha visión en paralelo, Villares establece tres cadros: a realidade física (xeográfica, humana), cultural e mais histórica de Galicia, os diversos intentos de interpretala e esoutro espello da Galicia emigrante en América. Debuxa o primeiro cadro, “Formación dunha nación-cultura” arredor de dous eixos: Terra, pobo e historia, e pais-nación; o segundo, “A procura dos antepasados”, con dous enfoques ou invencións: o celtismo e mais o medievalismo; e xa o terceiro, “A conexión americana” a partir dos destinos das migracións galegas.
Na primeira parte, desenrola diversos aspectos da dimensión nacional de Galicia. O primeiro, a súa conformación como nación cultural a falla da imposibilidade de acadar unha dimensión estatal. Apartado amplo no que reflexiona da contorna xeográfica do país (desde a Gallaecia histórica) na cal os seus habitantes, ao longo dos séculos, foron conformando unha comunidade con diversas aportacións, invasoras ou non.
Salienta, especialmente, a estruturación demográfica e relixiosa encetada por Martiño de Dumio durante a época sueva e a súa posterior relación co réxime feudal e a emerxencia das primeiras cidades medievais. E nese tema, o papel central de Xelmírez e a diverxencia entre Galicia e o emerxente condado de Portugal, ben axiña convertido en reino con Afonso Henriques.
Momento aquel que sempre foi visto con nostalxia polos galeguistas –actitude da que non escapa Villares- en tanto en canto Galicia non foi capaz de dar o mesmo paso. Non hai dúbida do proveito renovador que supuxo o enxerto dos borgoñóns Raimundo e Henrique coas fillas de Afonso VI. Pero se o fillo do segundo acadou a independencia portuguesa, o do primeiro, Afonso VII, estableceu as bases da futura expansión de León e Castela. E perante ambas empresas, a nobreza galaica (comezando polos Traba) dividiuse a prol delas (sen esquecer a segunda vaga que supuxo a conquista do val do Guadalquivir). Ante tales circunstancias e unha vez en decadencia o camiño a Compostela, Galicia ficou desconectada dos centros de poder.
E pasados os séculos, os primeiros esforzos para recuperar a identidade galega a partir do Rexurdimento (aceptemos esta denominación para entendermos) e das Irmandades da Fala, empresa frustrada polas consecuencias da sublevación militar de 1936. E nesa vontade de recuperación, Villares analiza a procura dos antepasados, con dúas vías empregadas: o celtismo e mais o medievalismo. O primeiro, a remolque da mitificación encetada en Escocia e Francia, especialmente, e o segundo, ao fío dos estudos históricos e do descubrimento dos cancioneiros medievais.
E a terceira parte, a conexión americana de Galicia, especialmente a partir das migracións masivas, que Villares focaliza –a maneira de fenomenoloxía- en tres cidades: Buenos Aires, La Habana e São Paulo. Destinos diferentes por diferentes circunstancias. Salienta dúas características, especialmente no caso da Arxentina: a nula implicación coa política local, a repetición en destino das dimensións nucleares de orixe (concellos) e, consecuencia diso, a ausencia dunha filantropía de gran dimensión, ficando reducida a microfilantropías colectivas (a prol dunha escola, por exemplo). Pero a análise non pasa disto. Non hai explicación das causas da emigración e non hai apenas autocrítica dos efectos en destino da mesma, seguindo a ignorancia que case sempre observou a crítica galega (salvemos a Xosé Lesta Meis): pouca repercusión na formación de elites, explotación dos chegados de novo por parte de familiares, vinculación co réxime franquista fronte aos sectores galeguistas.
Con todo, cabe saudar este exercicio de reflexión para entendermos e que entendan Galicia e a importancia da súa conexión americana, sen a cal –por ausencias e por presenzas- non se pode analizar a realidade galega do século XX.
text:
Ramón Villares: “We cannot think of modern Galicia without that other American Galicia”
05 Nov 2019, 05:38 by JOAQUIM VENTURA


Book cover

In any construction of an identity (therefore, with a national vocation), there are several phases: delimiting the object, attributing it to the status of subject, and getting the patients - it should be said - the patients, the nationals that make it up, to become aware of such uniqueness. Of course, it can happen that others give it to that historical object-subject without the natural ones becoming aware of it.
Maybe that's why exercises like what Ramón Villares does with Galicia. A nation between two worlds (Past & Present) wants to explain to the non-Galician readers the historical reality of this land but it does so with an (involuntary?) Reflection exercise whose recipients would be the Galicians themselves.
At the same time, but with a parallel vision, Villares establishes three frameworks: the physical (geographical, human), cultural and historical reality of Galicia, the various attempts to interpret it and the other mirror of the emigrant Galicia in America. Draw the first picture, “Formation of a nation-culture” around two axes: Earth, people and history, and country-nation; the second, "The search for ancestors", with two approaches or inventions: Celtism and medievalism; and the third, "The American connection" from the destinations of Galician migrations.
In the first part, he develops various aspects of the national dimension of Galicia. First, its conformation as a cultural nation fails the impossibility of achieving a state dimension. Extensive section that reflects on the geographical environment of the country (from the historical Gallaecia) in which its inhabitants, over the centuries, have been forming a community with diverse contributions, invading or not.
Particularly noteworthy is the demographic and religious structuring undertaken by Martiño de Dumio during the Swedish era and its subsequent relationship with the feudal regime and the emergence of the early medieval cities. And in that subject, the central role of Xelmírez and the divergence between Galicia and the emerging county of Portugal, soon become kingdom with Afonso Henriques.
A moment that has always been viewed with nostalgia by the Galician people - an attitude that Villares does not escape - as long as Galicia has not been able to take the same step. There is no doubt about the renewing benefit of the graft of the Burgundians Raimundo and Henrique with the daughters of Alfonso VI. But if the son of the second gained Portuguese independence, the son of the first, Alfonso VII, laid the foundations for the future expansion of León and Castile. And for both companies, the Gallic nobility (starting with the Traba) divided for them (not to mention the second strike that led to the conquest of the Guadalquivir Valley). Given these circumstances and once the path to Compostela was in decline, Galicia was disconnected from the centers of power.
And over the centuries, the first efforts to recover the Galician identity from the Resurgence (we accept this name to understand ourselves) and the Brotherhoods of Speech, a company frustrated by the consequences of the military uprising of 1936. And in that will of recovery, Villares analyzes the search of the ancestors, with two ways used: Celtism and medievalism. The first one, the towing of the mythification started in Scotland and France, in particular, and the second, the thread of historical studies and the discovery of medieval songbooks.
And the third part, the American connection of Galicia, especially from the massive migrations, that Villares focuses - in the manner of phenomenology - in three cities: Buenos Aires, Havana and São Paulo. Different destinations due to different circumstances. It highlights two characteristics, especially in the case of Argentina: the lack of involvement with local politics, the repetition in destination of the nuclear dimensions of origin (municipalities) and, consequently, the absence of a large philanthropy, being reduced to collective microfilanthropies (pro of a school, for example). But the analysis does not pass from this. There is no explanation of the causes of emigration and there is hardly any self-criticism of the effects to its destination, following the ignorance that has almost always been observed by Galician critics (save Xosé Lesta Meis): little impact on the formation of elites, exploitation of newcomers by part of family members, links with the Franco regime against the Galician sectors.
However, this exercise of reflection can be welcomed to understand us and to understand Galicia and the importance of its American connection, without which - due to absence and presence - the Galician reality of the 20th century cannot be analyzed.
